Housing is health care—especially during a pandemic. I’m so proud of this effort in Atlanta to combat homelessness—and after the passage of the expansive COVID relief package, I’m glad more help is on the way to help Georgians keep roofs over their heads. 
https://www.ajc.com/news/atlanta-news/covid-relief-funding-helps-move-450-of-atlantas-homeless-into-their-own-apartments/K2PM5LQLJRGUNJST5EWE3KDNS4/

Small businesses all across Georgia have struggled to keep their doors open during the pandemic. The #AmericanRescuePlan is going to help Main Street get back on its feet by bolstering the Paycheck Protection Program, investing in finance programs & extending grant options.

This month, Georgia lawmakers voted on bills to curb absentee voting & limit weekend voting. 
 
This is blatant voter suppression. It’s not restoring voter integrity—it's an attempt to cherry pick the electorate. The Senate must act now & pass the For the People Act.

Our children learn best when they’re in the classroom. 

The #AmericanRescuePlan is going to help Georgia students & educators safely resume in-person learning by providing funding for PPE, contact tracing, ventilation system repairs & more. https://www.ajc.com/education/georgia-schools-to-get-over-4-billion-from-latest-federal-stimulus/ZBGGUK65IZBHRFC53UJRYV3WFM/

On Wednesday, March 17, at 12:45pm ET, I’ll take the floor of the Senate to defend the very foundation of our democracy –– the sacred right to vote.

I promise you, Georgia, I will never stop fighting to protect & expand access to the ballot box. #TheVoteIsSacred http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwnpzTdWYAECWJN.jpg

La Jolla Boulevard is an unfair citation for frustration with roundabouts. It’s rather a rare and worthy example of a neighborhood that took a big leap, did a hard thing and transformed itself for the better. https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/columnists/logan-jenkins/sd-me-20170217-story.html
And you *should* visit, because it’s awesome. #BirdRock http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ewpstn3VIAU4SgD.jpg

And at that cafe you might hear a long time resident explain to a skeptic like the one @Freakonomics cited that, well actually roundabouts are safer and convey traffic more efficiently than traffic lights - that’s why we made the city put them in.

So if you come visit, you can now enjoy a sidewalk cafe or a quiet stroll without yelling over traffic noise or risking your life crossing the boulevard. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwpstUwUcAIUHIX.jpg
The La Jolla Boulevard redevelopment won a lot of local and national engineering and planning awards. And it made the neighborhood prettier, safer and chill.

The construction was painful because the boulevard was torn up for so long - each intersection had to go from an X to an O. We all tried to support the local businesses to get them through it. @BirdRockCoffee @beaumontslj And we did. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ewpss6zVoAAOfqj.jpg

We permitted the project through the city and CA Coastal Commission. We added 138 units (#YIMBY) and had the developer build two roundabouts instead of signals. We put together another $5.6M and built out the project - as the community envisioned it - in 2007 and 2008.

The neighbors supported the plan because they had great leadership (eg @JoeLaCavaD1), learned the issues. vetted the ideas and helped design it themselves. I had to promise to build what they designed - as long as they didn’t propose tunnels or bridges (they didn’t). http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwpssaWUUAUwRel.jpg

As your piece suggested, there was wide and deep skepticism about doing something so different. But we had a concept and the chance to do something great. So together, a lot of residents, engineers and at least one politician took a big risk. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwpssJ0UUAAew8t.jpg

We didn’t know about the English roundabout guy in your podcast, “Lord of the Rings.” We used an Australian traffic consultant, Michael Wallwork, “Roundabout Dundee.” Credit to the city traffic staff who learned from him and bought in. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwpsrxXUcAwtBie.jpg

Dan led a walking tour of the neighborhood, then conferred with the neighbors about their concerns. A few weeks later he came back and proposed a re-design, including 5 roundabouts on the main road, with mini roundabouts on the side streets. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwpsreiVIAUUZkx.jpg

I hired the community their own walkability consultant - Dan Burden of Port Townsend WA @DanBurden2 - and invited and empowered them to fashion the answer neighbor to neighbor. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwpsrNjVEAETAGV.jpg

The community wanted a fix but the typical city traffic engineer solutions - lights and diagonal parking - seemed half baked. People were so frustrated and angry. It would have been easy to quit. But the boulevard was bad, I was new, didn’t know better, and I wouldn’t do nothing.

When I joined the San Diego City Council in 2000, La Jolla Boulevard was an 68-foot wide seven-lane thoroughfare through a neighborhood, with cars traveling at highway speeds. Nobody wanted to shop, dine, or even walk there- too noisy, messy, scary. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ewpsq4QVoAIO9sz.jpg

They were only “existing” because the community had undertaken a seven-year project to remake their neighborhood with roundabouts. You talked with your guests about how hard this is to do and then missed this great and relevant story - so here it is.
I almost fell off my chair when the only reference to La Jolla was of one single resident complaining about “existing“ roundabouts.

This is a great listen on how modern roundabouts reduce congestion, fuel consumption, pollution and traffic crash deaths over signalized intersections. I recommend it. #projectzero HOWEVER https://twitter.com/Freakonomics/status/1371170106651377667 QT @Freakonomics Americans are so accustomed to the standard intersection that we rarely consider how dangerous it can be — as well as costly, time-wasting, and polluting. Is it time to embrace the lowly, lovely roundabout? Listen here: https://link.chtbl.com/U_nQbfjl

7/ It's horrible for our nation's security when the defense budget continues to increase by tens of billions each year while funding for diplomacy remains flat.

Even with a $12B increase, our international affairs budget would still be less than 1/10th of our military spending.

6/ On climate change, no time to waste. We're proposing $3B for the Green Climate Fund to help developing countries invest in climate solutions, and funding to promote the export of US green energy technology.
5/ Next, pandemic prevention: we're proposing $6B in new funding for global health programs, including new investments in the @WHO and @CEPIvaccines to help us detect and prevent emerging threats.

4/ The best way to counter China is with strong economic diplomacy and an expanded US diplomatic presence overseas. We're proposing an additional $135M to counter disinformation, deploying 1500 new diplomats, and doubling investments in development projects.

3/ China is running circles around the US when it comes to deploying diplomats and development funding. And their state-sponsored propaganda arm is working nonstop to discredit free and open democracies. We can't continue to let them go unchallenged.

2/ I'm teaming up with @ChrisVanHollen, @davidcicilline & @RepBera to propose a $12 billion increase in funding for State and USAID directed towards three specific challenges - competing with China, preparing for the next pandemic, and fighting climate change.

The biggest national security threats we face today - climate change, pandemic disease, China competition - can't be solved with military tools.

But today we spend 13x - THIRTEEN TIMES! - more on the military than on diplomacy/smart power.

Through participation and leadership, members of civil society are habituated in observing their shared values, cooperating with their fellow men, and ultimately in practicing self-government.

The mediating institutions “mediate” by securing for the individual a space for participation, membership, & belonging within the broader society. In this way, civil society is thought to prevent individuals’ estrangement and alienation from mass society. https://jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis/?id=78A35E07-4C86-44A2-8480-BE0DB8CB104E

Structural independence enables civil society to serve a functional role as a set of “mediating institutions.” Institutions—the durable social arrangements we create together to achieve common goals in the course of interacting with one another—are created for many reasons.

Civil society constitutes a kind of “third sector” within society. It exists independently of both government, or the “public sector,” and the market, or “private sector.” Learn more about the importance of civil society in America ↓

Housing vouchers are proven as one of the most effective policies for reducing homelessness and housing insecurity among low-income people and underserved communities.

I want to thank the PHAs & other housing advocates who helped so we can support those who are struggling most.

That's why I introduced the Ensuring a Long-Term Housing Recovery Act which will invest in new housing vouchers that eligible households can stay on until their income returns to normal. 
https://adamsmith.house.gov/press-releases?id=E6E46B68-231F-40C5-A4E9-9BF507A9F246

Investing in single-issue vouchers for all income-eligible families through the Public Housing Authorities maximizes our ability to reach households in need of support and ensures that emergency rental assistance will be efficiently distributed and last as long as people need it.

The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the existing affordable housing crisis facing far too many families. As many renters struggle to pay for the essentials, we must invest heavily in our most efficient and effective programs available for providing rental assistance.

Today I’m voting to extend the bipartisan Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) that was set to expire at the end of March.
 
So many businesses in CT & across the nation have been able to stay afloat because of this federal program & I’m proud to vote to extend it until June 30th.
For more information on stimulus checks visit https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/economic-impact-payment-information-center

What if I don’t usually file taxes?

The IRS is urging people who don’t normally file a tax return to look into their filing options. Visit https://irs.gov/filing for more information about options available.

What if the IRS does not have my information?

You can input your direct deposit information using the IRS’s “Get My Payment” tool, see link below!
https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/get-my-payment

How will I get my payment?

Payments will be directly deposited into bank accounts, or come in the mail as a paper check or debit card. Visit the IRS’s "Get My Payment” tool to find out how the IRS will be delivering your payment.

What do I need to do to claim my payment?

Most eligible people will get the 3rd stimulus check automatically & won’t need to take more action. The IRS will use available information from your most recent tax return to determine eligibility & which bank account to send it to.

Do qualifying dependents also receive a check? What about adult dependents?

Yes and yes! Qualifying families receive $1,400 for each dependent. That includes adult dependents over the age of 17 too! So if you’re a single mother with 2 dependents, you will receive $4,200!

Will I get a stimulus check if I make over 75K?

Maybe. Individuals making under $80,000 and married filers making under $160,000 will receive a reduced payment. Households over those incomes will not receive a payment.

Who qualifies for a stimulus check, and how much would I get?

If you’re a single filer and earn less than $75,0000 annually you qualify. If you’re married & filing jointly and earn less than $150,000 you qualify! Qualifying individuals will receive $1,400
